issue.title: [DOC] documentation to summarize the classification algorithms and their categories

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Describe the issue linked to the documentation

Entry into the world of TSC requires external reading
 
#### Suggest a potential alternative/fix

A description of the categories of algorithms, summary of the TSC algorithms available  and links to the relevant papers would be really helpful

issue.title: [ENH] data set simulators/generators

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
As discussed in #320, it would be great to have functions that generate/simulate data sets, they are useful for testing and explaining the difference between estimators. 

* We currently have a very simple data set generator here: [`make_classification_problem`](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/67c56be8b1e838f2628df829946f795b7dba9aed/sktime/utils/_testing/series_as_features.py#L33)
* TSML has some here in Java: https://github.com/uea-machine-learning/tsml/tree/master/src/main/java/statistics/simulators

issue.title: User guide

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
#361 

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
* skeleton of new user guide 

#### Implementation
- [x] the user guide should live in the documentation on our [website](https://sktime.org) on a separate page
- [x] we need to add a new `user_guide.rst` file to [/docs/source](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/tree/master/docs/source), and link and collect chapters in `/docs/source/user_guide/`,
- [ ] new pages can be added as Jupyter notebooks or rst files, feel free to replace stub pages 
- [ ] add links to algorithm class docstrings 
- [ ] cross-reference example notebooks

#### PR checklist
- [x] change back `nbsphinx_execute = 'never'` to `always` in `conf.py`

body: Hi @fkiraly and @lynnssi, I've create a PR with a framework for the user guide #377.

issue.title: Acknowledgements

repository.name: Time-Series-Analysis-in-Sktime
repository.description: This repository will hold all the code files (jupyter notebok) for the YouTube tutorial on sktime on datageekrj

issue.body:
Hi @datageekrj, thanks for creating the sktime video tutorials! I've linked them in our wiki. We're looking for people to help us write our documentation and user guide, would that be something you're interested in? 

I can also add you to our list of contributors following the all-contributor specification if you like.

issue.title: Initial work on generators for #353 Data set simulators/generators

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at
the extension guidelines: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->

Initial work on generators based on mention in #353 with @mloning.

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented. 
-->

This introduces univariate generators for random normal noise, ARMA process, and linear process with noise.

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one? 

<!--
If your contribution does add a new dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate
 companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum. 
-->

No new dependencies.

#### PR checklist for new estimators 
<!--
This is only relevant if you contribute a new estimator
 (classifiers, regressors, forecasters, etc
.). If so, please go through the checklist below. Otherwise please ignore check list.

- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally. 
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.
- [ ] I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/CODEOWNERS) and I'm committed to maintain my algorithm.
- [ ] I've added myself to the list of contributors
-->

Not a new estimator.

#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.

Thanks for contributing!
-->

body: Another idea: We could also invite people to upload their blogposts in form of Jupyter notebooks to a blog post repo, something along the lines of https://github.com/fastai/fastpages for sktime.

I'm happy to contribute either through the docs directly or via a notebook or two if that would help and build it out from there?

So do the intro first, then the TS transformations and then the TS regression/forecasting examples. Not too familiar with TS classification but happy to collaborate or give it a dig if someone can point me in a cool real world data set.

Hi @evanmiller29, if you want to contribute to the docs directly, best to work off and merge into #377. The preliminary table of contents above should give a basic scaffolding for the sections. For the notebooks, best to look at the examples and improve them.

Hi @lynnssi and @fkiraly, I've now merged the basic structure of the user guide (#377) with a note that it's under development and that we're looking for contributions. 

@lynnssi I've added a page for extra resources - perhaps it's best to start the curated list of blog posts there? Feel free to edit/move around pages as you see fit.
